channel.title: BBC News - Science & Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Climate change: Arctic warming linked to colder winters
item.description: A new study connects the heating of the Arctic region to extreme winter weather in the US.

item.title: Paddle boarder's close encounter with two curious whales
item.description: A drone filmed what the paddle boarder, out on the water on her birthday, calls a "magical moment".

item.title: Breeding seabird numbers in Scotland almost halved since 1980s
item.description: A new study by NatureScot looked at 11 species of breeding birds in Scotland over the last 35 years.

item.title: Climate-above-all plea by US fails to stir China
item.description: Envoy John Kerry's 'it's more important than politics' appeal falls on deaf ears.

item.title: International Space Station facing irreparable failures, Russia warns
item.description: The majority of in-flight systems on the ISS have passed their expiry date, an official warns.

item.title: Climate change: Big increase in weather disasters over the past five decades
item.description: Floods, storms and extreme events increase five-fold but the number of people dying in them fell.

item.title: Hurricane Ida: Before and after images reveal devastation
item.description: Aerial photographs reveal damage and flooding in parts of Louisiana following Hurricane Ida.

item.title: One in three trees face extinction in wild, says new report
item.description: Experts say 17,500 tree species are at risk around the world, including magnolias, oaks and maples.

item.title: Greta Thunberg: Scotland not a world leader on climate change
item.description: Speaking ahead of Glasgow's COP26, the activist says no country in the "global north" is doing enough.

item.title: Climate change: Europe's 2020 heat reached 'troubling' level
item.description: Temperatures in Europe in 2020 broke the previous high mark by a worrying margin say scientists.

item.title: Climate Basics: Can carbon offsetting help the planet?
item.description: BBC Reality Check looks at whether it's possible to buy your way out of creating harmful greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Climate change: Europe's extreme rains made more likely by humans
item.description: Heavy rainfall that led to deadly floods in Germany and Belgium was influenced by human induced warming.

item.title: Could this solar farm be a climate change solution?
item.description: UN experts say rapid innovative solutions are needed to end our dependency on fossil fuels. Could this new project provide an answer?

item.title: Madagascar on the brink of climate change-induced famine
item.description: The country is on the brink of experiencing the world's first "climate change famine", the UN says.

item.title: Climate change: Will I still be able to fly in a net zero world?
item.description: A new study asks if lifestyle changes including an end to flying will be necessary to reach net zero?

item.title: Pulsar discoverer awarded Royal Society's highest prize
item.description: Astrophysicist Dame Jocelyn Bell Burnell is only the second woman to be awarded the Copley Medal.

item.title: Astronomers see galaxies in ultra-high definition
item.description: Researchers capture some of the most detailed images ever seen of galaxies in deep space.

item.title: Bezos sues Nasa over its deal with Elon Musk's SpaceX
item.description: Mr Bezos's Blue Origin says it was unfairly treated after being excluded from lunar landing contract.

item.title: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft: A guide
item.description: Starliner is one of two vehicles designed to transport astronauts to and from the space station.

item.title: Wildlife photo: Is this the world's most beautiful mosquito?
item.description: Both beauty and beast. A Sabethes mosquito is visually stunning but it's also a carrier of disease.

item.title: Majestic birds caught by the camera
item.description: A selection of the winners in this year's Bird Photographer of the Year competition.

item.title: Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards 2021 finalists revealed
item.description: An angry starling and a lounging bear were also among the competition finalists.

item.title: Does feeding garden birds do more harm than good?
item.description: How bird feeding could disrupt an ecological balance just beyond our windowsills and gardens.

item.title: Greenland island is world's northernmost island - scientists
item.description: They say a tiny island off Greenland's coast was discovered by luck during a recent expedition.

item.title: Covid origin: US spy agencies publish 'inconclusive' report
item.description: The office that oversees US spy agencies could not establish how the coronavirus pandemic began.

item.title: Theranos scandal: Who is Elizabeth Holmes and why is she on trial?
item.description: The former boss of blood testing company Theranos is accused of fraud and could face years in jail.

item.title: From earrings to tiles – what you can do with plastic waste
item.description: How people around the world are recycling plastic waste themselves and turning it into cool stuff.

item.title: US lab stands on threshold of key nuclear fusion goal
item.description: A US science institute is on the verge of achieving a longstanding goal in nuclear fusion research.

item.title: The zero-power sewage plant inspired by cows
item.description: Fifty sustainable sewage treatment plants have been built that work in similar way to a cow's stomach.

item.title: Search for Covid's origins stalled, scientists say
item.description: "The window of opportunity" for crucial studies into how the Covid-19 pandemic started is closing, scientists say.
